questions.text: A 17-year-old female with no previous medical history, was brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision. During evaluation, hyphema in the left eye was detected. Which of the following conditions does not require surgical intervention?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Total hyphema within 1 hour

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. IOP ≥ 25 mmHg for > 5 Days : Elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) is a significant concern in hyphema . Persistent elevation (IOP ≥ 25 mmHg for more than 5 days) despite medical therapy (like topical beta-blockers, alpha agonists, and systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors) may indicate the need for surgical intervention . This is to prevent optic nerve damage and other complications associated with prolonged elevated IOP.
  • • Option A.
  • • IOP ≥ 25 mmHg for > 5 Days
  • • Elevated intraocular pressure
  • • hyphema
  • • Persistent elevation
  • • despite medical therapy
  • • indicate the need for surgical intervention
  • • Option B. Corneal Blood Staining : This occurs when red blood cells and hemoglobin infiltrate the corneal stroma . It is a severe complication of hyphema, especially in the setting of high IOP . Corneal blood staining is more likely when there is total hyphema or repeated bleeding. Surgical intervention is often recommended to prevent permanent visual impairment due to corneal opacity.
  • • Option B.
  • • Corneal Blood Staining
  • • occurs when red blood cells
  • • hemoglobin infiltrate the corneal stroma
  • • severe complication of hyphema, especially in the setting of high IOP
  • • Option C. IOP > 50 mmHg for >24 Hours : This is a critical condition. An IOP greater than 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours is a medical emergency due to the risk of optic nerve damage and other complications, such as corneal blood staining. Immediate surgical intervention is typically required to reduce the pressure and prevent irreversible damage.
  • • Option C.
  • • IOP > 50 mmHg for >24 Hours
  • • IOP greater than 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours is a medical emergency due to the risk of optic nerve damage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of hyphema following trauma , surgical intervention is typically indicated for IOP ≥ 25 mmHg lasting more than 5 days , corneal blood staining, and IOP > 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours . However, total hyphema within 1 hour of injury usually does not require immediate surgical intervention unless complications develop.
  • ➤ management of hyphema following trauma
  • ➤ surgical intervention
  • ➤ IOP ≥ 25 mmHg lasting more than 5 days
  • ➤ IOP > 50 mmHg lasting more than 24 hours
  • ➤ Ref : American association of ophthalmology. Https://eyewiki.aao.org/hyphema
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : American association of ophthalmology. Https://eyewiki.aao.org/hyphema
  • ➤ 2. https://www.aao.org/education/bcscsnippetdetail.aspx?id=31b9e6a0-5abe-4f7c-b457-ceafadddab3d

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sign of a blow-out fracture of orbit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Exophthalmos

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Diplopia : It is a common symptom of blow-out fractures , often resulting from impaired movement of the affected eye due to muscle entrapment or nerve damage.
  • • Option B.
  • • Diplopia
  • • common symptom of blow-out fractures
  • • resulting from impaired movement
  • • Option C. Enophthalmos : This is the posterior displacement of the eye within the orbit , leading to a sunken appearance. It is a characteristic sign of blow-out fractures. The increase in the orbital volume caused by the fracture allows the eyeball to sink backward.
  • • Option C.
  • • Enophthalmos
  • • posterior displacement of the eye within the orbit
  • • sunken appearance.
  • • Option D. Infraorbital nerve anesthesia : This refers to a loss of sensation in the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve , typically the lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip . It can occur in blow-out fractures if the fracture involves the infraorbital groove or canal, where the nerve runs.
  • • Option D.
  • • Infraorbital nerve anesthesia
  • • loss of sensation in the area supplied by the infraorbital nerve
  • • lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Enophthalmos, not exophthalmos , is a sign of blow-out fracture of the orbit . Blow-out fractures typically increase orbital volume , allowing the eyeball to sink backward , leading to enophthalmos , rather than protruding forward as in exophthalmos.
  • ➤ Enophthalmos, not exophthalmos
  • ➤ sign of blow-out fracture of the orbit
  • ➤ increase orbital volume
  • ➤ eyeball to sink backward
  • ➤ enophthalmos
  • ➤ protruding forward as in exophthalmos.
  • ➤ Ref : pg 864 kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 864 kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of intermittent tearing from her left eye. Examination reveals no significant eye redness or visual impairment. She mentions the symptoms are more pronounced in windy conditions or when she is tired. Further examination of the eyelid function reveals a slight delay in tear drainage. Which part of the orbicularis oculi muscle, involved in tear drainage and commonly affected in such cases, is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lacrimal (Horner’s muscle)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Orbital Part : This part of the orbicularis oculi muscle is involved in the forceful closure of the eyelids , as in blinking . It's not directly involved in tear drainage.
  • • Option A.
  • • Orbital Part
  • • orbicularis oculi muscle
  • • forceful closure of the eyelids
  • • blinking
  • • Option B. Temporal Part : This is not a distinct part of the orbicularis oculi muscle ; rather, the muscle has palpebral and orbital parts . The temporal part does not relate to tear drainage.
  • • Option B.
  • • Temporal Part
  • • not a distinct part of the orbicularis oculi muscle
  • • muscle has palpebral and orbital parts
  • • Option D. Muller’s Muscle : Muller's muscle, or the superior tarsal muscle , is a smooth muscle that contributes to eyelid elevation . It is not a part of the orbicularis oculi muscle and does not influence tear drainage.
  • • Option D.
  • • Muller’s Muscle
  • • superior tarsal muscle
  • • smooth muscle
  • • contributes to eyelid elevation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Horner’s muscle refers to the lacrimal part of the orbicularis oculi muscle , which is integral in tear drainage.
  • ➤ Horner’s muscle
  • ➤ lacrimal part of the orbicularis oculi muscle
  • ➤ integral in tear drainage.
  • ➤ Ref : pg 492/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 492/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: The only extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Muller’s muscle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Superior Rectus : This muscle, responsible for elevating the eye , is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III), not by sympathetic nerves.
  • • Option A.
  • • Superior Rectus
  • • responsible for elevating the eye
  • • innervated by the oculomotor nerve
  • • Option B. Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS) : The LPS raises the upper eyelid and is also innervated by the oculomotor nerve . It is not supplied by sympathetic nerves.
  • • Option B.
  • • Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS)
  • • raises the upper eyelid
  • • innervated by the oculomotor nerve
  • • Optiion C. Medial Rectus : This muscle, which moves the eye medially (towards the nose), is innervated by the oculomotor nerve as well . It does not receive sympathetic innervation.
  • • Optiion C.
  • • Medial Rectus
  • • moves the eye medially
  • • innervated by the oculomotor nerve as well

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The only extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is Müller’s Muscle , a smooth muscle in the upper eyelid that aids in eyelid elevation.
  • ➤ extraocular muscle with sympathetic nerve supply is Müller’s Muscle
  • ➤ Ref : pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : pg 497/ Anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: Which is the thickest wall of the orbit?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lateral wall

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Medial Wall : The medial wall of the orbit is one of the thinnest and most fragile parts . It is formed primarily by the ethmoid bone and partly by the lacrimal bone , the frontal bone , and the lesser wing of the sphenoid. This wall separates the orbital cavity from the ethmoid air cells , making it prone to injury and subsequent communication with the nasal cavity.
  • • Option A
  • • Medial Wall
  • • medial wall of the orbit
  • • thinnest and most fragile parts
  • • formed primarily by the ethmoid bone
  • • lacrimal bone
  • • frontal bone
  • • lesser wing of the sphenoid.
  • • wall separates the orbital cavity from the ethmoid air cells
  • • Option C . Roof : The roof of the orbit is formed primarily by the orbital plate of the frontal bone and, to a lesser extent , by the lesser wing of the sphenoid . It separates the orbital contents from the anterior cranial fossa and provides protection from superior impacts . It's relatively thin compared to the lateral wall but stronger than the medial wall.
  • • Option C
  • • Roof
  • • roof of the orbit is formed primarily by the orbital plate
  • • frontal bone
  • • lesser extent
  • • lesser wing of the sphenoid
  • • separates the orbital
  • • anterior cranial fossa
  • • provides protection from superior impacts
  • • Option D . Floor : The floor of the orbit is formed by the orbital surface of the maxillary bone , along with small contributions from the zygomatic bone and the palatine bone . This wall is thin and vulnerable to fractures , especially from trauma to the orbit, as it separates the orbital contents from the maxillary sinus.
  • • Option D
  • • Floor
  • • formed by the orbital surface
  • • maxillary bone
  • • small contributions
  • • zygomatic bone
  • • palatine bone
  • • wall is thin
  • • vulnerable to fractures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral wall is the thickest wall of the orbit , providing substantial protection to the eye from lateral impacts , and distinguishing itself in strength and thickness from the more fragile medial wall , the moderately strong roof , and the thin, vulnerable floor of the orbit .
  • ➤ lateral wall is the thickest wall of the orbit
  • ➤ substantial protection to the eye from lateral impacts
  • ➤ strength and thickness from the more fragile medial wall
  • ➤ moderately strong roof
  • ➤ thin, vulnerable floor of the orbit
  • ➤ Ref : pg 578/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA
  • ➤ Ref : pg 578/ anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3 rd edition/ AK KHURANA

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a two-day history of severe headache, fever, and double vision. She recently had a dental abscess treated. On examination, she has a temperature of 38.5°C, and her visual examination shows impaired lateral movement of the right eye. There is no ptosis or pupillary abnormality. Her facial sensation is intact. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain shows evidence suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which cranial nerve is most likely involved first in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Abducent

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Oculomotor (Cranial Nerve III) : This nerve controls most of the eye's movements , the constriction of the pupil , and maintains an open eyelid . In cavernous sinus thrombosis , its involvement typically results in ptosis (drooping eyelid), pupillary dilation, and limited eye movement except for lateral and downward gaze.
  • • Option A. Oculomotor (Cranial Nerve III)
  • • nerve controls most of the eye's movements
  • • constriction of the pupil
  • • maintains an open eyelid
  • • cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • • results in ptosis
  • • Option B. Trochlear (Cranial Nerve IV) : This nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle , which is responsible for downward and lateral eye movement . Its involvement would lead to vertical diplopia, particularly when looking down.
  • • Option B. Trochlear (Cranial Nerve IV)
  • • nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle
  • • downward and lateral eye movement
  • • Option D. Trigeminal (Cranial Nerve V) : This nerve is responsible for facial sensation and motor functions of the muscles of mastication . Involvement in cavernous sinus thrombosis would cause facial sensory loss and chewing difficulties but not eye movement disorders.
  • • Option D. Trigeminal (Cranial Nerve V)
  • • nerve is responsible for facial sensation
  • • motor functions of the muscles of mastication

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cavernous sinus thrombosis , the abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) is typically the earliest to be affected due to its vulnerability within the cavernous sinus , often presenting with an inability to abduct the eye and resulting in horizontal diplopia .
  • ➤ cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • ➤ abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI)
  • ➤ earliest to be affected due to its vulnerability
  • ➤ cavernous sinus
  • ➤ presenting
  • ➤ inability to abduct the eye
  • ➤ horizontal diplopia
  • ➤ Ref : pg 412,6th edition, comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref : pg 412,6th edition, comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by his parents who are concerned about his unusual eyelid movement. They report that every time he suckles while breastfeeding, his right upper eyelid retracts unusually. There is no history of trauma or surgery. On examination, you notice that the right upper eyelid droops slightly in a neutral facial expression and elevates when the infant is smiling or crying. This condition is likely due to an aberrant connection between the muscles innervated by which two cranial nerves?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 & 5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. 3 & 7 : This option suggests a connection between the oculomotor nerve (CN III), which innervates the levator palpebrae superioris (responsible for eyelid elevation), and the facial nerve (CN VII), which controls facial expressions .
  • • Option A. 3 & 7
  • • :
  • • connection between the oculomotor nerve
  • • innervates the levator palpebrae superioris
  • • facial nerve
  • • controls facial expressions
  • • Option B. 4 & 5 : The trochlear nerve (CN IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle of the eye , and the trigeminal nerve (CN V) is responsible for facial sensation and mastication . An aberrant connection here is unlikely to cause the described eyelid phenomenon.
  • • Option B. 4 & 5
  • • trochlear nerve
  • • superior oblique muscle of the eye
  • • trigeminal nerve
  • • facial sensation and mastication
  • • Option D. 5 & 7 : This option suggests a connection between the trigeminal nerve (CN V) and the facial nerve (CN VII). While the facial nerve is involved in facial expressions , the trigeminal nerve's role in sensation and mastication does not typically lead to eyelid synkinesis.
  • • Option D. 5 & 7
  • • connection between the trigeminal nerve
  • • facial nerve
  • • facial nerve is involved in facial expressions
  • • trigeminal nerve's role in sensation and mastication

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ For medical students preparing for residency, it's essential to understand that congenital synkinetic ptosis typically results from an aberrant innervation between the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and the motor division of Trigeminal nerve (CN V), leading to an unusual elevation of the eyelid during facial movements like smiling or crying.
  • ➤ congenital synkinetic ptosis
  • ➤ aberrant innervation between the oculomotor nerve
  • ➤ motor division of Trigeminal nerve
  • ➤ unusual elevation of the eyelid
  • ➤ Ref : pg 41, eyelids -kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 41, eyelids -kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition.
  • ➤ 2. Demirci H, Frueh BR, Nelson CC. Marcus Gunn jaw-winking synkinesis: clinical features and management. Ophthalmology. 2010 Jul;117(7):1447-52. doi: 10.1016/j.ophtha.2009.11.014. Epub 2010 Feb 25. PMID: 20188419.
  • ➤ 2. Demirci H, Frueh BR, Nelson CC. Marcus Gunn jaw-winking synkinesis: clinical features and management. Ophthalmology. 2010 Jul;117(7):1447-52. doi: 10.1016/j.ophtha.2009.11.014. Epub 2010 Feb 25. PMID: 20188419.

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient came with the complaint of shortness of breath. On examination, fullness in the right supraclavicular region is observed. On ocular examination, right pupil is constricted. Which of the following is not a feature of the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Heterochromia Iridis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Ptosis: This is a hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome. It occurs due to paralysis of the Müller's muscle, a sympathetically innervated muscle in the eyelid, leading to a slight drooping of the upper eyelid.
  • • Option A. Ptosis:
  • • hallmark feature of Horner's syndrome.
  • • Option B. Anhidrosis: This refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face . It is a feature of Horner's syndrome due to the disruption of sympathetic nerves that innervate sweat glands.
  • • Option B. Anhidrosis:
  • • refers to the absence or decrease in sweating on the affected side of the face
  • • Option D. Enophthalmos: This refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance. While mild enophthalmos can be associated with Horner's syndrome due to the lack of sympathetic tone to the orbitalis muscle, it is not as prominent or diagnostic as the other features.
  • • Option D. Enophthalmos:
  • • refers to the posterior displacement of the eyeball within the orbit, leading to a sunken appearance.
  • • Conclusion:
  • • Conclusion:
  • • Heterochromia iridis is not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome. The classic triad of Horner's syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos being a less prominent associated feature.
  • • Heterochromia iridis
  • • not a typical feature of adult onset Horner's syndrome.
  • • triad of Horner's syndrome
  • • ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, with enophthalmos
  • • Ref : pg344/anatomy & physiology of eye 3 rd edition – ak Khurana (pg 575)
  • • Ref : pg344/anatomy & physiology of eye 3 rd edition – ak Khurana (pg 575)

questions.text: A patient present with proptosis, vision changes, and eye pain. After thorough examination and imaging, the ophthalmologist makes the diagnosis of an orbital tumour. Which is the most common benign orbital tumour in adults?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cavernous haemangioma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Rhabdomyosarcoma : This is a type of malignant tumor that arises from skeletal muscle. It is the most common primary orbital malignancy in children , not adults.
  • • Option A.
  • • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • • malignant tumor
  • • arises from skeletal muscle.
  • • common primary orbital malignancy in children
  • • Option C. Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma : This represents a group of blood cancers that develop in the lymphatic system. While it can involve the orbit, it is not classified as a benign tumor . Orbital involvement in non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma usually indicates a systemic disease rather than a primary orbital tumor.
  • • Option C.
  • • Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • • group of blood cancers
  • • lymphatic system.
  • • involve the orbit, it is not classified as a benign tumor
  • • Option D . Neuroblastoma : This is a malignant tumor that arises from nerve tissue . It is most commonly seen in children and is not a benign tumor.
  • • Option D
  • • Neuroblastoma
  • • malignant tumor
  • • arises from nerve tissue
  • • most commonly seen in children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common benign orbital tumor in adults is a cavernous hemangioma.
  • ➤ common benign orbital tumor in adults
  • ➤ cavernous hemangioma.
  • ➤ Ref : pg 102/orbit/kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition.
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 102/orbit/kanski’s clinical ophthalmology 8 th edition.

questions.text: In a 32-year-old female presenting with muscle tremors and palpitations, ocular examination reveals proptosis, eyelid retraction, and restricted eye movements. Graves' disease is suspected, and further investigations are underway for confirmation. What is the sequence of involvement of extraocular muscles in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Superior rectus> Lateral rectus> Inferior rectus> Medial rectus

options.label: B
options.text: Lateral rectus> Inferior rectus> Medial rectus> Superior rectus

options.label: C
options.text: Medial rectus> Superior rectus> Lateral rectus> Inferior rectus

options.label: D
options.text: Inferior rectus> Medial rectus> Superior rectus> Lateral rectus

questions.correct_answer: D. Inferior rectus> Medial rectus> Superior rectus> Lateral rectus
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Inferior rectus> Medial rectus> Superior rectus> Lateral rectus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • The sequence of involvement of the extraocular muscles in Graves' ophthalmopathy typically follows a specific pattern:
  • • extraocular muscles in Graves' ophthalmopathy
  • • Inferior Rectus Muscle : This muscle is most commonly affected first . Its involvement leads to restricted upward gaze and may contribute to the appearance of exophthalmos . Medial Rectus Muscle : Following the inferior rectus , the medial rectus is often the next muscle to be involved. Its dysfunction can result in limited lateral gaze . Superior Rectus Muscle : This muscle, often affected concurrently with the levator palpebrae superioris ( responsible for eyelid elevation), can lead to difficulties in downward gaze . Lateral Rectus Muscle : This muscle is less commonly affected than the others , but its involvement can lead to limited medial gaze. Superior Oblique Muscle : This muscle is the least commonly affected in Graves' ophthalmopathy .
  • • Inferior Rectus Muscle : This muscle is most commonly affected first . Its involvement leads to restricted upward gaze and may contribute to the appearance of exophthalmos .
  • • Inferior Rectus Muscle
  • • muscle is most commonly affected first
  • • upward gaze
  • • contribute to the appearance of exophthalmos
  • • Medial Rectus Muscle : Following the inferior rectus , the medial rectus is often the next muscle to be involved. Its dysfunction can result in limited lateral gaze .
  • • Medial Rectus Muscle
  • • inferior rectus
  • • medial rectus
  • • next muscle to be involved.
  • • dysfunction
  • • limited lateral gaze
  • • Superior Rectus Muscle : This muscle, often affected concurrently with the levator palpebrae superioris ( responsible for eyelid elevation), can lead to difficulties in downward gaze .
  • • Superior Rectus Muscle
  • • affected concurrently with the levator palpebrae superioris (
  • • difficulties in downward gaze
  • • Lateral Rectus Muscle : This muscle is less commonly affected than the others , but its involvement can lead to limited medial gaze.
  • • Lateral Rectus Muscle
  • • less commonly affected than the others
  • • Superior Oblique Muscle : This muscle is the least commonly affected in Graves' ophthalmopathy .
  • • Superior Oblique Muscle
  • • least commonly affected in Graves' ophthalmopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient with an alleged history of assault was reported at the department of oral and maxillofacial surgery with orbital ecchymosis, periorbital oedema, subconjunctival haemorrhage and tenderness in the infraorbital region. Limitation of which of the following extra ocular movement occurs?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Elevation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Depression (Inferior Rectus Muscle) : Normally, the inferior rectus muscle facilitates the depression of the eyeball (looking downward). In orbital floor fractures , the inferior rectus muscle can be entrapped or edematous, leading to restricted movement. However, this typically results in difficulty with elevation due to inhibited action against the superior rectus muscle, rather than depression itself.
  • • Option A.
  • • Depression (Inferior Rectus Muscle)
  • • inferior rectus muscle facilitates the depression of the eyeball
  • • orbital floor fractures
  • • inferior rectus muscle can be entrapped
  • • Option B. Intorsion (Superior Oblique Muscle) : Intorsion, or inward rotation of the eyeball , is controlled by the superior oblique muscle . Orbital floor fractures usually do not impact the trochlear nerve or the superior oblique muscle, so intorsion is generally unaffected.
  • • Option B.
  • • Intorsion (Superior Oblique Muscle)
  • • inward rotation of the eyeball
  • • superior oblique muscle
  • • Option D. Abduction (Lateral Rectus Muscle) : Abduction, the movement of the eyeball outward , away from the nose, is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle . This movement is typically not affected in orbital floor fractures as the lateral rectus muscle and its nerve supply (abducens nerve) are not involved in the trauma.
  • • Option D.
  • • Abduction (Lateral Rectus Muscle)
  • • movement of the eyeball outward
  • • controlled by the lateral rectus muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the context of an orbital floor fracture , the most commonly affected extraocular movement is elevation , primarily due to the entrapment or impairment of the inferior rectus muscle , which creates resistance against the superior rectus muscle responsible for elevating the eye.
  • ➤ orbital floor fracture
  • ➤ most commonly affected extraocular movement is elevation
  • ➤ entrapment or impairment of the inferior rectus muscle
  • ➤ creates resistance
  • ➤ Ref : pg 423/ orbit/ 6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana
  • ➤ Ref
  • ➤ : pg 423/ orbit/ 6 th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

questions.text: Identify the sign:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Von graefe’s sign

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Dalrymple's Sign : This is characterized by an abnormal widening of the palpebral fissure due to retraction of the upper eyelid , giving the appearance of a stare .
  • • Option A.
  • • Dalrymple's Sign
  • • characterized by an abnormal widening of the palpebral fissure
  • • retraction of the upper eyelid
  • • appearance of a stare
  • • Option C. Stellwag's Sign : This sign is marked by a reduced frequency or absence of blinking , contributing to the characteristic stare of Graves' disease .
  • • Option C.
  • • Stellwag's Sign
  • • marked by a reduced frequency
  • • absence of blinking
  • • characteristic stare of Graves' disease
  • • Option D. Sign : It indicates an inability or weakness in maintaining convergence of the eyes , often observed during prolonged focusing on a near object .

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient gave an alleged history of RTA leading to injury to right eye. He presented with severe proptosis, chemosis, diplopia and an orbital bruit three weeks after the accident. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Orbital Cellulitis : An infection of the orbital tissues resulting in painful eye movements , redness , swelling , and sometimes impaired vision . While it can cause proptosis and diplopia, the absence of an orbital bruit and the acute onset of symptoms post-trauma make it less likely in this scenario.

However, it usually develops gradually and does not produce an orbital bruit , which makes it an unlikely diagnosis in this acute post-traumatic setting.
  • • Option C.
  • • Thyroid Orbitopathy
  • • autoimmune thyroid disease
  • • presents with eyelid retraction, proptosis, and diplopia
  • • not produce an orbital bruit
  • • Option D. Preseptal Cellulitis : Involves the eyelid and periorbital skin without affecting the orbit itself . Symptoms include eyelid redness and swelling. It doesn’t typically cause proptosis, diplopia, or an orbital bruit, and it's unrelated to the kind of trauma described in the scenario.

  • • Involves the eyelid and periorbital skin without affecting the orbit itself

questions.text: In a 35-year-old woman with a history of right eye ptosis for 6 months, the eyelids appear asymmetrical, and the ptosis fluctuates throughout the day, worsening in the evening. The fatigability test shows positive results. Which of the following tests is not helpful in diagnosing the condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Snap back test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Edrophonium Test : This test is useful in diagnosing MG . Edrophonium, a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor , temporarily increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction , leading to an improvement in muscle strength in patients with MG.
  • • Option A.
  • • Edrophonium Test
  • • useful in diagnosing MG
  • • short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor
  • • increases the availability of acetylcholine
  • • neuromuscular junction
  • • Option B. Ice Pack Test : This test is also helpful in MG . Cooling improves neuromuscular transmission , and thus, application of an ice pack on the eyelids can temporarily improve ptosis in MG.
  • • Option B.
  • • Ice Pack Test
  • • test is also helpful in MG
  • • Cooling
  • • neuromuscular transmission
  • • Option D. Electromyography (EMG) : EMG, especially single-fiber EMG, is a key diagnostic tool in MG . It measures the electrical activity of muscles and can detect the characteristic patterns of neuromuscular transmission failure seen in MG.
  • • Option D.
  • • Electromyography (EMG)
  • • single-fiber EMG,
  • • diagnostic tool in MG

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of 5 days of progressive left facial swelling and fever. On ocular inspection, left periorbital oedema, erythema and discharge are noted. On examination, left eye showed decrease in visual acuity, and the pupil showed relative afferent pupillary defect. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. AV Malformation (Arteriovenous Malformation) : This is an abnormal connection between arteries and veins , bypassing the capillary system . It can cause swelling and other issues due to altered blood flow , but it typically does not present with infection-like symptoms (fever, discharge) or a rapid onset of visual changes and RAPD.
  • • Option A.
  • • AV Malformation (Arteriovenous Malformation)
  • • abnormal connection between arteries and veins
  • • bypassing the capillary system
  • • cause swelling
  • • altered blood flow
  • • does not present with infection-like symptoms
  • • Option C. Retinoblastoma : A malignant tumor of the retina , common in children . It usually presents with a white pupillary reflex (leukocoria) and may cause vision loss . However, retinoblastoma does not typically cause fever , periorbital edema, or erythema, which are indicative of an infectious process.
  • • Option C.
  • • Retinoblastoma
  • • malignant tumor of the retina
  • • children
  • • white pupillary reflex
  • • cause vision loss
  • • retinoblastoma
  • • not typically cause fever
  • • Option D. Neuroblastoma : A cancer that develops from immature nerve cells , mostly occurring in children . It can present with various symptoms depending on the site of the tumor but is unlikely to cause localized periorbital edema , erythema, and discharge without other systemic or neurological symptoms.
  • • Option D.
  • • Neuroblastoma
  • • cancer that develops from immature nerve cells
  • • children
  • • site of the tumor
  • • unlikely
  • • cause localized periorbital edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a pediatric patient presenting with fever , progressive facial swelling , periorbital edema , erythema , discharge , decreased visual acuity , and RAPD , the most probable diagnosis is Orbital Cellulitis , an infectious condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the orbital tissues, often requiring prompt medical intervention.

  • ➤ erythema

  • ➤ decreased visual acuity
  • ➤ RAPD

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of gradual protrusion of the right eye over the past few months. The patient reports no pain or visual disturbances but is concerned about the noticeable change in eye position. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist notices axial proptosis (forward displacement) of the right eye. Further evaluation reveals a palpable resistance to retropulsion of the globe suggestive of a mass behind the eye. Which surgical space in the orbit is most likely involved in this case, causing the axial proptosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intraconal space

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . Extraconal Space : This space lies outside the muscle cone , between the orbital bones and the orbital septum . While masses here can cause proptosis, they typically do not cause the globe to resist retropulsion as much as intraconal masses do.
  • • Option A
  • • Extraconal Space
  • • space lies outside the muscle cone
  • • orbital bones and the orbital septum
  • • Option B. Subperiosteal Space : This space is located between the periosteum and the orbital bones. While subperiosteal hematomas or abscesses can cause proptosis, they are usually more localized and do not commonly result in a palpable resistance to retropulsion of the globe.
  • • Option B.
  • • Subperiosteal Space
  • • located between the periosteum and the orbital bones.
  • • Option D. Subtenon’s Space : This space lies between the sclera and Tenon’s capsule . Lesions in this space are less likely to cause significant proptosis or resistance to retropulsion as compared to intraconal lesions.
  • • Option D.
  • • Subtenon’s Space
  • • between the sclera and Tenon’s capsule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of axial proptosis with palpable resistance to retropulsion of the globe , the intraconal space of the orbit is most likely involved.

questions.text: At what stage of gestation does the development of the eyeball begin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Day 22

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Day 1 : This marks the beginning of gestation when fertilization typically occurs . At this stage, the zygote (fertilized egg) is just beginning to undergo cell division . There is no specific organ development occurring yet, including the development of the eyeball.
  • • Option A.
  • • Day 1
  • • marks the beginning of gestation when fertilization typically occurs
  • • zygote
  • • beginning to undergo cell division
  • • Option B. Day 30 : By this time, major developmental processes are underway , but this is past the initial formation of the eye structures. The eye begins to develop earlier than day 30 .
  • • Option B.
  • • Day 30
  • • major developmental processes are underway
  • • past the initial formation of the eye structures.
  • • eye begins to develop earlier than day 30
  • • Option D. Day 7 : At this stage, the embryo is undergoing implantation in the uterine wall . There is no specific organ development occurring at this early stage, including the eyes.
  • • Option D.
  • • Day 7
  • • embryo is undergoing implantation in the uterine wall

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The development of the eyeball begins around Day 22 of gestation with the formation of the optic grooves or sulci , leading to the development of optic vesicles .
  • ➤ development of the eyeball begins around Day 22
  • ➤ gestation with the formation of the optic grooves or sulci
  • ➤ development of optic vesicles

questions.text: Which structure of the eye marks the boundary for the anterior segment, including all the structures located in front of it?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Crystalline lens

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cornea : The cornea is the transparent anteriormost structure of the eyeball .
  • • Option A.
  • • Cornea
  • • transparent anteriormost structure of the eyeball
  • • Option C. Iris : The iris is the pigmented part of the eye that controls the size of the pupil and amount of light that enters the eye . It is part of the anterior segment but does not define its boundary. The iris-pupillary plane divides the anterior segment of eye into anterior chamber and posterior chamber.
  • • Option C.
  • • Iris
  • • pigmented part of the eye that controls the size of the pupil
  • • amount of light that enters the eye
  • • anterior segment
  • • iris-pupillary plane divides the anterior segment of eye into anterior chamber and posterior chamber.
  • • Option D. Vitreous : The vitreous is a clear gel that fills the space between the lens and the retina in the posterior segment of the eye.
  • • Option D.
  • • Vitreous
  • • vitreous is a clear gel
  • • space between the lens and the retina

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with leukocoria (white glow) in the right eye and occasional eye pain. Clinical examination reveals a white, elevated mass with vascular changes in the posterior segment of the eye. The posterior segment of the eyeball encompasses structures located behind which specific part of the eye?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Posterior surface lens

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Pupil : The pupil is the opening in the center of the iris that allows light to enter the eye . The iris-pupil plane divides the anterior segment of the eye into anterior chamber and posterior chamber .
  • • Option A.
  • • Pupil
  • • opening in the center of the iris that allows light to enter the eye
  • • iris-pupil plane divides the anterior segment
  • • anterior chamber and posterior chamber
  • • Option B . Ciliary body : The ciliary body is part of the eye's uveal tract and is situated behind the iris. It controls the shape of the lens and produces aqueous humor, but it is not the dividing line between the anterior and posterior segments.
  • • Option B
  • • Ciliary body
  • • eye's uveal tract
  • • situated behind the iris.
  • • Option C . Anterior surface of lens : The anterior surface of the lens is the front part of the lens . It would be more accurate to consider the entire lens as the dividing structure, rather than just its anterior surface.
  • • Option C
  • • Anterior surface of lens
  • • front part of the lens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior segment of the eyeball encompasses structures located behind the posterior surface of the lens .
  • ➤ posterior segment of the eyeball encompasses structures
  • ➤ behind the posterior surface of the lens
